issue.title: PHPStan doesn't recognize class properties within a declare_tick() block
issue.body:
### Bug report

When declaring a `declare()` block, phpstan loses references to class property instances. (See added snippet)

### Code snippet that reproduces the problem

https://phpstan.org/r/0f14ff7b-ee3a-4273-a475-d7653f44517d

### Expected output

Expected error is " No Errors" see snippet

https://phpstan.org/r/4b53a9d4-def4-403b-b942-6c06b3285eac

### Did PHPStan help you today? Did it make you happy in any way?

Love your work Ondrej

issue.title: memory consumption because of big functionMap
issue.body: ### Bug report since phpstan build jobs are failling because of out of memory issues, see e.g. [extension-tests / Extension Tests (7.4, phpstan-doctrine)](https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan-src/actions/runs/6531991567/job/17734491236?pr=2666#logs) ``` php vendor/bin/phpunit PHPUnit 9.6.13 by Sebastian Bergmann and contributors. Warning: No code coverage driver available ............................................................... 63 / 362 ( 17%) S...........................SS..SS............SS............... 126 / 362 ( 34%) PHP Fatal error: Allowed memory size of 805306368 bytes exhausted (tried to allocate 135168 bytes) in phar:///home/runner/work/phpstan-src/phpstan-src/extension/vendor/phpstan/phpstan/phpstan.phar/resources/functionMap.php on line 12219 .............................S..........SS Fatal error: Allowed memory size of 805306368 bytes exhausted (tried to allocate 135168 bytes) in phar:///home/runner/work/phpstan-src/phpstan-src/extension/vendor/phpstan/phpstan/phpstan.phar/resources/functionMap.php on line 12219 make: *** [Makefile:6: tests] Error 255 ``` I did some measures, which suggested that - in the doctrine extension case - the signature map is taking the biggest part of it this measures were verified by clearing the functionMap via `file_put_contents('phar://phpstan.phar/resources/functionMap.php', ' with a cleared functionMap the job uses 140MB less memory. ### Expected output maybe we can remove some stuff from the functionMap to reduce this overhead?

issue.title: Trait & Interface is not working
issue.body:
### Bug report

Seems like the intersection between trait and interface doesn't work as the intersection between 2 interfaces.

### Code snippet that reproduces the problem

https://phpstan.org/r/efc614c7-ed04-435b-ad1a-5b280ac8944a

### Expected output

The line `$obj->fMyTrait();` should not emit problems as `$obj->fMyInterfaceB();` does.

### Did PHPStan help you today? Did it make you happy in any way?

PHPStan helps me every day.

issue.title: PHPStan assumes DOMDocument::load() returns mixed
issue.body:
### Bug report

PHPStan seems to assume that `DOMDocument::load()` returns `mixed` and not `bool` as stated in the documentation.

https://www.php.net/manual/en/domdocument.load.php

The documentation does however mention from version 8.3 onwards it will return a "tentative bool" whatever that may mean (quantum bits?). But I get the error even though I have explicitly specified the PHP version as 8.1.

### Code snippet that reproduces the problem

https://phpstan.org/r/00db931e-075f-4f74-8f2f-58df9e3003db

### Expected output

No errors.

### Did PHPStan help you today? Did it make you happy in any way?

PHPStan helps me everyday by saving me from my own errors.

comment.body: Please send a PR that updates resources/functionMap.php in phpstan-src.

issue.title: Phpstan Pro: Mapping source files support
issue.body: Hi! I'm running phpstan pro in docker, which disallows to click through link into IDE. Is there any way how to configure path mappings (simple str_replace is enough)? :-)

issue.title: Run analysis with level 9, but use a lower level for tests
issue.body:
### Feature request

This has already been asked at least one time, and @ondrejmirtes responded:

> Hi, I’d recommend you to generate the baseline on level 6 and use PHPStan on that level for your whole codebase. You shouldn’t have the need to regenerate it, you shouldn’t allow any new errors to be added.
> 
> Also it’d definitely help you to get rid of the most frequent errors, you can lower the number of errors if you focus on the most annoying.
> 
> For the tool to be less annoying I’d recommend you to set reportUnmatchedIgnoredErrors  to false. https://phpstan.org/user-guide/ignoring-errors#reporting-unused-ignores
> 
> I have no plans to allow different level per path because that’s what the baseline is for. But you can do that if you run PHPStan multiple times on multiple directories, it should be doable with a single config file. You can reuse parts of the config file with “includes”: https://phpstan.org/config-reference#multiple-files
> 
> _Originally posted by @ondrejmirtes in https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan/issues/3640#issuecomment-661116509_
> 

I agree that one can use the baseline to ignore certain errors. And we do too.

We run our project with level 9 because we want strictness in our `src` code that hits production. But I notice that tests now become tedious to write:

For example, this is a valid PHPunit test:
```php
$token = new SomeToken('https://some-url');
$result = json_decode(base64_decode((string) $id, true), true, 512, JSON_THROW_ON_ERROR);

self::assertSame('https://some-url', $result['webhookEndpoint']);
self::assertIsInt($result['createdAt']);
```

Simple and to the point. Since the unit test passes, we know the code works. 
If sometimes changes along the way, the test will fail. 

But PHPStan is (rightfully) not happy:

- Parameter #1 $json of function json_decode expects string, string|false given.
- Cannot access offset 'webhookEndpoint' on mixed.
- Cannot access offset 'createdAt' on mixed.

So I need to write it like this:
```php
$token = new SomeToken('https://some-url');
$json = base64_decode((string) $token, true);
self::assertNotFalse($json); // base64_decode can return false, so we remove that

$result = json_decode($json, true, 512, JSON_THROW_ON_ERROR);

self::assertIsArray($result); // go from mixed to array
self::assertArrayHasKey('webhookEndpoint', $result); // assert the key exists
self::assertSame('https://some-url', $result['webhookEndpoint']);
self::assertArrayHasKey('createdAt', $result); // assert the key exists
self::assertIsInt($result['createdAt']);
```

This is just a simple example, but this really takes out the joy of writing a simple unit test.

A solution to this could be to create a separate config for the `tests` directory. But this leads to other issues: 
* PHPStorm doesn't understand this
* We always have to run PHPStan twice, on a large codebase (15000+ classes) this becomes slow


### Did PHPStan help you today? Did it make you happy in any way?

I interact with PHPStan whole day, and it helps me spot so many potential problems that I couldn't have spotted with just unit testing :blue

issue.title: Conditional argument type not properly narrowing type (for constant string unions?)
issue.body:
### Bug report

When having a function with a union of (constant) strings as argument and a second parameter for which the type depends on the other argument one could use a conditional parameter type (`@param ($param1 is 'foo' ? int : bool) $param2`). This only seems to happen when the union type consists of more than 2 types. This as, as far as I tried to debug it and understood the code, the conditional parameter type is split in two `ConditionalExpressionHolders`, one for the [true condition](https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan-src/blob/80ce9a404787133ff3fa266f90602728bf1c349c/src/Analyser/MutatingScope.php#L2680C4-L2680C4) and one for the [false condition](https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan-src/blob/80ce9a404787133ff3fa266f90602728bf1c349c/src/Analyser/MutatingScope.php#L2685C6-L2685C6). These conditions are based on `TypeCombinator::intersect` and `TypeCombinator::remove` where supplied arguments are the type of the argument the condition is compared too and the supplied condition type. For the supplied example this thus leads to two `ConditionalExpressionHolders`, one of `ConstantStringType('value3')` which results in a boolean and one of `UnionType([ConstantStringType('value1'), ConstantStringType('value2')])` which results in a integer.
Later on when the these [conditional expressions are tested](https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan-src/blob/80ce9a404787133ff3fa266f90602728bf1c349c/src/Analyser/MutatingScope.php#L3826C79-L3826C79). But in this case for the match arms / conditions on `'value1'` and `'value2'` these comparisons fail. This as the `ConstantStringType` (containing the `value1` / `value2` as value) are tested for equality against the `UnionType` which fails.

There are also scenario's which result in other (un)expected results. In case where `$param1` consists only of 2 types (`'value1'|'value2'`, without `|'value3'`) it always seems to work fine for example, as in that case the `TypeCombinator::intersect` and `TypeCombinator::remove` calls both result in a `ConstantStringType` which will obviously be fine for the comparison. But when changing the order of the match arms, so `'value3'` is the first condition it also works fine.

### Code snippet that reproduces the problem

https://phpstan.org/r/5b254792-1ecd-49ed-a140-930184c7a820

### Expected output

No errors.

And applying `\PHPStan\dumpType($param2)` in the match arms should thus result in: value1 => int, value2 => int, value3 => bool.

### Did PHPStan help you today? Did it make you happy in any way?

_No response_

comment.body:
Note: I did an investigation to find out how these conditional parameter types work, as I'm unfamiliar with them, and (thus) also trying to find out whether I hit a bug or was just using it wrong.

Furthermore I would like to contribute, if possible (or would have submitted just a PR if the fix seemed easy). But as I'm new to PHPStan (as a user) I'm not gonna touch the code "just yet" on what seems such a rather complex issue. But with some pointers in a direction for a fix I might still be able to create a PR for this.

Some general ideas I have been thinking about which _might_ work / solve this is either creating these `ConditionalExpressionHolders` for every possible value/type in the union. So in this case that would mean splitting the result of `TypeCombinator::remove`, which is the `'value1'|'value2'` union, in it's parts, so `'value1'` and `'value2'`, and creating the "same" `ConditionalExpressionHolders` for both (obviously with the different types supplied).
Another solution might be to change the `equals` implementation so it will match a union when any value in the union matches. But my guess is that affects a lot of code/logic (i.e.: `->equals` being called from lots of places) so doesn't seem like a smart move. But it might also be some other comparison can be used? (quickly glancing `ConstantStringType` and `UnionType` it _might_ be that `isSuperTypeOf` works? As that seems to still compare proper values when comparing two `ConstantStringTypes`, and in case of a `UnionType` does an `or` on all the values).

issue.title: Conditional argument type not properly narrowing type (for constant string unions?)
issue.body:
### Bug report

When having a function with a union of (constant) strings as argument and a second parameter for which the type depends on the other argument one could use a conditional parameter type (`@param ($param1 is 'foo' ? int : bool) $param2`). This only seems to happen when the union type consists of more than 2 types. This as, as far as I tried to debug it and understood the code, the conditional parameter type is split in two `ConditionalExpressionHolders`, one for the [true condition](https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan-src/blob/80ce9a404787133ff3fa266f90602728bf1c349c/src/Analyser/MutatingScope.php#L2680C4-L2680C4) and one for the [false condition](https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan-src/blob/80ce9a404787133ff3fa266f90602728bf1c349c/src/Analyser/MutatingScope.php#L2685C6-L2685C6). These conditions are based on `TypeCombinator::intersect` and `TypeCombinator::remove` where supplied arguments are the type of the argument the condition is compared too and the supplied condition type. For the supplied example this thus leads to two `ConditionalExpressionHolders`, one of `ConstantStringType('value3')` which results in a boolean and one of `UnionType([ConstantStringType('value1'), ConstantStringType('value2')])` which results in a integer.
Later on when the these [conditional expressions are tested](https://github.com/phpstan/phpstan-src/blob/80ce9a404787133ff3fa266f90602728bf1c349c/src/Analyser/MutatingScope.php#L3826C79-L3826C79). But in this case for the match arms / conditions on `'value1'` and `'value2'` these comparisons fail. This as the `ConstantStringType` (containing the `value1` / `value2` as value) are tested for equality against the `UnionType` which fails.

There are also scenario's which result in other (un)expected results. In case where `$param1` consists only of 2 types (`'value1'|'value2'`, without `|'value3'`) it always seems to work fine for example, as in that case the `TypeCombinator::intersect` and `TypeCombinator::remove` calls both result in a `ConstantStringType` which will obviously be fine for the comparison. But when changing the order of the match arms, so `'value3'` is the first condition it also works fine.

### Code snippet that reproduces the problem

https://phpstan.org/r/5b254792-1ecd-49ed-a140-930184c7a820

### Expected output

No errors.

And applying `\PHPStan\dumpType($param2` should thus result in the match arms should thus result in: value1 => int, value2 => int, value3 => bool.

### Did PHPStan help you today? Did it make you happy in any way?

_No response_

issue.title: Array intersection support
issue.body:
# Feature request

PHPStan should be able to understand `array{p: int}&array<string, string>`.  
I use it in cases when part of array is dynamic and part is known with fixed shape.

https://phpstan.org/r/7b1a6e08-c0de-41f2-932b-54e9305a6058

> PHPDoc tag @param for parameter $i contains unresolvable type.

(https://psalm.dev/r/1914dd6087)

comment.body:
Was mighty confused by reading all the docs on intersections, and then discovering it simply didn't do anything.

In Symfony's OptionResolver you can extend classes and therefore their array based (and validated!) configs. This is a poster case for importing the typed based config array with `@phpstan-import-type` and then extending it with an intersection.

Made a test case of what I would expect to work and was surprised to discover didn't yet: https://phpstan.org/r/25721ba5-2c7f-40bc-9a4b-3f704f0ea4fb

issue.title: Call to static method Assert::allNotNull() with array will always evaluate to true
issue.body:
### Bug report

After the update of `phpstan/phpstan` from 1.6.5 to 1.10.39, and `phpstan/phpstan-webmozart-assert` from 1.1.2 to 1.2.4, and I got a new error
`Call to static method Webmozart\Assert\Assert::allNotNull() with array will always evaluate to true.`

for a piece of code

```php
    /**
     * @param list<string> $ids
     *
     * @return list<Account>
     */
    private function accounts(array $ids): array
    {
        $accounts = array_map(fn (string $id): ?Account => $this->accounts->find($id), $ids);

        Assert::allNotNull($accounts);

        return $accounts;
    }
```

which looks like a bug, because when I dump types, it seems that allNotNull itself is working perfectly fine

```
79     Dumped type: list<Account|null>                                        
80     Call to static method Webmozart\Assert\Assert::allNotNull() with array will always evaluate to true.  
81     Dumped type: list<Account>
```

Maybe there's a stub telling that `allNotNull` checks the value for null, not the values of the iterable?

I've also tried to downgrade the `phpstan/phpstan-webmozart-assert` without a luck, that's why I ended up creating an issue in this repo. I also have the latest version (1.11.0) of the `webmozart/assert`, it that helps.

### Code snippet that reproduces the problem

Would be happy to reproduce it in the playground, but it doesn't include all the plugins, so it's not really possible. :(

### Expected output

There should be no error it this case.

### Did PHPStan help you today? Did it make you happy in any way?

I always have lots of fun finding even more code or annotations to fix in our ~7k file code base and finding some weird stuff after each PHPStan update. Each time I think "now we've fixed everything", but each time PHPStan proves me wrong. :))

issue.title: Call to static method Assert::allNotNull() with array will always evaluate to true
issue.body:
### Bug report

After the update of `phpstan/phpstan` from 1.6.5 to 1.10.39, and `phpstan/phpstan-webmozart-assert` from 1.1.2 to 1.2.4, and I got a new error
`Call to static method Webmozart\Assert\Assert::allNotNull() with array will always evaluate to true.`

for a piece of code

```php
    /**
     * @param list<string> $ids
     *
     * @return list<Account>
     */
    private function accounts(array $ids): array
    {
        $accounts = array_map(fn (string $id): ?Account => $this->accounts->find($id), $ids);

        Assert::allNotNull($accounts);

        return $accounts;
    }
```

which looks like a bug, because when I dump types, it seems that allNotNull itself is working perfectly fine

```
79     Dumped type: list<Rbk\Payments\DataBundle\Entity\Account|null>                                        
80     Call to static method Webmozart\Assert\Assert::allNotNull() with array will always evaluate to true.  
81     Dumped type: list<Rbk\Payments\DataBundle\Entity\Account>
```

Maybe there's a stub telling that `allNotNull` checks the value for null, not the values of the iterable?

I've also tried to downgrade the `phpstan/phpstan-webmozart-assert` without a luck, that's why I ended up creating an issue in this repo. I also have the latest version (1.11.0) of the `webmozart/assert`, it that helps.

### Code snippet that reproduces the problem

Would be happy to reproduce it in the playground, but it doesn't include all the plugins, so it's not really possible. :(

### Expected output

There should be no error it this case.

### Did PHPStan help you today? Did it make you happy in any way?

I always have lots of fun finding even more code or annotations to fix in our ~7k file code base and finding some weird stuff after each PHPStan update. Each time I think "now we've fixed everything", but each time PHPStan proves me wrong. :))

comment.body: Oh, it seems the error is not caused by the update, but rather by setting the `treatPhpDocTypesAsCertain` to `false`. But still I can't get what's wrong in that code.
